fields.description:
Would be nice to have the ability to have a short cut to push after a commit. 

For example, cmd + enter commits your changes, shift + cmd + enter would be useful as a "commit, then push" shortcut
fields.summary: Push after commit shortcut

fields.description: In the log view, please allow to navigate to a commit's child easily. Navigating to a commit's parent is already possible by clicking on the according SHA-1 in the revision panel. Just listing the child's SHA-1 with a link in the same way would be great. This would be similar to how gitk is doing it for git.
fields.summary: Allow to navigate to a commit's child easily

fields.description: Here's a video that shows how this frustrating behaviour doubles the work I have to do to perform a seemingly primitive action: http://screencast.com/t/dTawDyEjy7I
fields.summary: Reconsider what effect Reset/Revert should have on untracked files

fields.description: I will probably get slapped on the head, but, any hope for a Windows version?
fields.summary: A windows port

fields.description: Toolbar item should be there for the Bookmarks that drops down a sheet with your bookmarks for easy access, instead of a separate modeless window.
fields.summary: Bookmarks - all in one with the main window

fields.description:
Problem: Amending commits only shows the diff from the committed state to the current state.

Wish: An Option to switch between the current view = "show diff of changes to the commit that's being amended" and "show diff of the commit after the amend". (see TortoiseGit "Show diff to last commit" feature: http://wiki.typo3.org/wiki/images/0/0c/Tortoisegit_amend_commit.gif)

Benefits:
* You see what the commit will look like.
* You can unstage/revert changes from a commit by amending it.
fields.summary: Amend: Option to Show Whole Diff

fields.description:
Steps to reproduce:
1. create git repo Y which contains a submodule pointing to git repo Z
2. create a new git repo X
3. add submodule to X that points to Y
Note, that the repo Z will not be updated (directory is empty)
Console output from adding submodule (repo names changed):
git -c diff.mnemonicprefix=false -c core.quotepath=false submodule add -f git@git.assembla.com:Y.git sireal.sdk 
warning: templates not found /usr/local/git/share/git-core/templates
Cloning into 'Y.sdk'...
git -c diff.mnemonicprefix=false -c core.quotepath=false submodule init Y.sdk 
Completed successfully
fields.summary: git submodule update is not recursively called when adding a git submodule

fields.description:
SourceTree 1.5.5 is unstable on 10.6.8.
I tested it locally on 10.6.8 and it crashes upon start-up
fields.summary: SourceTree crashes on 10.6.8

fields.description:
Raised at https://answers.atlassian.com/questions/83511/sourcetree-cannot-find-git-flow-osx-mountain-lion#comment-96195

Using OSX 10.8.2, SourceTree 1.5.4, embedded git and git-flow:

The git-flow operation mentioned above (finish feature with rebase), now produces this error:

Will try to rebase 'testfeature'...
git: 'rebase' is not a git command. See 'git --help'.
Finish was aborted due to conflicts during rebase.
Please finish the rebase manually now.
When finished, re-run:
    git flow feature finish 'testfeature' 'develop'
I used the test case from the associated bug report:

https://jira.atlassian.com/browse/SRCTREE-1183

Steps:

unpack the test repo and import into SourceTree
check out feature/testfeature
run Git Flow -> Finish Current for Feature: testfeature.
check "Rebase on development" and click "OK"
Of course, I see the same problem in my own repos as well.

Perhaps the cause (additions to PATH required) is the same?  External Git + external git-flow works fine, e.g., git flow feature finish -r testfeature.
fields.summary: Git flow finish feature issue on Mountain Lion

fields.description:
I encountered a minor file status display bug while using hg copy to split one file into four. I used hg copy to create 3 new files and renamed the original file using hg move.

Two files (the first two that were copied) display correctly as "copied/renamed". Last copied file and renamed file display with label "deleted" and old file name instead of "copied/renamed from" and the correct file name. Here's the exact sequence that led to the misleading output:

Original file: display.css
First file: display.css -> copied to colors.css; I modified both display.css and colors.css at this point
Second file: Modified display.css -> copied to competitor.css; display.css and competitor.css both modified at this point
Third file: modified display.css -> copied to division.css; display.css and division.css both modified at this point
display.css -> moved to matchmaking.css

division.css and matchmaking.css display incorrectly

The files seem to save state correctly when I committed, so this appears to just be display problem, as far as I can tell.

See attachments
fields.summary: Mercurial file status display problem when doing multiple copy/rename operations on the same file

fields.description: Git no longer includes the original SHA as a comment in cherry-pick, you have to add the '-x' option to get it. Should be an option in the cherry-pick confirmation dialog (it was removed as a default from git to avoid mentioning SHAs which were only ever private branches).
fields.summary: Add -x option to git cherry-pick to include original SHA

fields.description:
Hi,

When trying to change the "strip" parameter with numeric keyboard input, the form effectively breaks.

1. The numeric input is doubled (so entering '5' will result in '55')
2. After the numeric input, the arrow buttons (up or down) don't function any more
fields.summary: The "strip" field of the Git Apply Patch dialog isn't editable with the keyboard

fields.description:
when trying to create a bookmark for a svn repository which files are in the root folder, SourceTree fails to convert the repository to either GIT or HG.

This could happen if the SVN repo is unusually organized - if it has a 'branches/' folder within the root, but also has files in the root.

SourceTree does a 'svn ls' to probe the repo, to figure out its structure
if it sees 'branches/' in there, it uses that option to the 'git svn clone'

however, using '--branches=branches' combined with having the 'trunk' in the root folder instead of inside 'trunk/' where it should be seems to screw git-svn up, it doesn't know how to cope with that structure.

As the branches folder seems to be empty, if you deleted that from the repo it would fix it probably.

If it is necessary to preserve this non "standard" SVN organization, it is possible to get around it with git-svn but only on the command line, because you have to know to ignore this folder. 

Could we make ST to ignore the branches/ folder (I guess but only by special-casing this scenario) if enough people (voters/watchers) are interested?
fields.summary: retrieve/convert a non standard svn repository

fields.description:
Every time I switch a branch this annoying dialogue appears. This happens even when there are no changes in the working directory and in those cases it also contains a redundant "Discard local changes" option.

http://screencast.com/t/XXH3AvaZCge5

Having to constantly approve such a basic action is extreeeemely annoying.
fields.summary: Annoying "Confirm branch switch" dialogue

fields.description:
Running latest SourceTree 1.5.4 on Snow Leopard 10.6.8 on MacBook Pro 17" 1920x1200 screen and the preview part on the Hgflow dialogs always have a horizontal scrollbar.

In addition, it would be nice if this dialog could be resized (with size being remembered) so it's possible to get more lines of history.
fields.summary: Hg flow: Preview part on dialogs is not wide enough resulting in horizontal scrollbar, which reduces preview height

fields.description:
1. Add/Commit an .as file to the DVCS.
2. Make a change to that .as file (and optionally add/commit).
3. View the diff using the internal diff tool (see attached screenshot).

The diff shows the entire file contents have been removed and added as opposed to highlighting the line changes.

This will occur for any ActionScript file added to the repository.
fields.summary: Visual diff not working for ActionScript (*.as) files

fields.description:
When errors occur on Git commit, merge, pull, etc provide a link to a web page that describes the error in plain English and how to resolve the issues. 

Expected Behavior
When committing a change in SourceTree received an error. Expected (wished) to see links to clear instructions how to solve said issues. 

Actual Behavior
Error messages were shown (vaguely remember one line suggestion that may have been part of Git error message) and I was not sure how to resolve the issues. I searched online until I found answers. The answers I found were in the form of git command line solutions which didn't always translate over to what I needed to do in SourceTree.
fields.summary: When error occurs show links to answers

fields.description:
https://answers.atlassian.com/questions/93171/does-sourcetree-1-5-4-on-a-mac-work-with-system-mercurial-version-2-3-1

Turns out they've changed something in hg 2.3 which breaks the hgsubversion extension and makes most hg commands fail.

Workaround: disable hgsubversion

Fix: probably need to update the embedded hgsubversion extension, but will need re-testing.
fields.summary: Mercurial 2.3 breaks hgsubversion

fields.description:
When applying a patch file which contains multiple commits in one patch file, SourceTree gives some .rej rejection files, which is to be expected. The problem is that if for a single source file, there were rejections for diffs in multiple commits, only the latest rejected diff is contained in the .rej file.

This is in fact the git/hg default behaviour when applying a patch file which contains multiple commits in one patch file.

One way to resolve this is to not use combined multi-commit patch files. SourceTree has an option to create one patch per commit for this reason when creating patches.

However this can be a lot of tedious work, for instance with over 25 separate patch files. 

A new feature suggestion for SourceTree would be to allows batch processing of patch files, i.e. one that allows to select multiple files which are then applied as patches subsequently. You could add an option that renames any .rej files created in each step to a unique name (maybe including the patch file name) to avoid the problem that .rej files get overwritten.
fields.summary: SourceTree should allow batch processing of patch files

fields.description: Now that I'm using a custom action instead of the toolbar Pull button (see SRCTREE-1217), I'd love to be able to put a button into the toolbar, context-sensitive to the relevant repos, that triggers the action.
fields.summary: Repo-level Custom Actions in Toolbar

fields.description:
llvm.org uses svn, but has an official git mirror that is synched in an svn commit hook. rebase = true is set.

SourceTree wants to do a git svn rebase, which is very slow since it's using svn. It would be way faster if I could get it to git fetch && git svn rebase -l instead.
fields.summary: Git mirror of svn project uses git svn rebase

fields.description:
My ssh-agent is configured to time out after a while. If SourceTree is running when ssh-agent is timed out and it decides to refresh everything, I end up with many dialog boxes asking for my ssh key passphrase – apparently one per project it is trying to refresh.

Once I enter my passphrase I then have to cancel all the other dialog boxes.
I realize this may be at least partly a Mac OS X issue, but I'm wondering if there is any way you can work around it, e.g. by only trying to refresh one project that uses ssh at a time; if the first one gets held up waiting for authorization then don't try to refresh the others yet.

I am on MacOS X 10.7.4;
fields.summary: Limit ssh authentication to 1 dialog box

fields.description: Have ST to detect if the .config file in the .git folder has the same URL added many times and fix it for the user.
fields.summary: ST to parse the git config file

fields.description:
Since GitHub "reworked" their definition of following/starred, those of us with large numbers of starred repos are left with a massive list in the Hosted Repositories window.

Eventually, I think the best route would be the addition of a filtering mechanism in that window, but I can't suggest a UX-friendly way to do that..

The simpler fix, for now, would be to add additional checkboxes in the 'Edit Account' dialog - "Show private repositories" is there now, so it's a logical place to add an additional "Show starred repositories".

[With the latter implementation it's important to note that starred repos can also be simultaneously followed.]
fields.summary: Hosted repositories browser should have display options for starred vs. followed repos on GitHub

fields.description:
When I'm viewing a changeset or an individual diff, I'd to have that take up the whole screen. What I usually want to do is to double-click on a changeset or a file diff and have that open as a new window that I can then zoom to full screen.

IMHO we lose a lot of space to the panel on the left and the changeset list at the top of the view.
fields.summary: Create new window for changeset and diff views

fields.description:
I'd like to be able to browse the entire file tree (isn't this called Source Tree?) and jump directly to the log/blame view for any file, regardless of whether I've made any changes to it.

This is sort of like SRCTREE-931 and SRCTREE-821. IMHO this differs from 821 in that I don't want to have to search, I just want a tree view on the current repo contents. It's similar to 931, but again, there isn't an easy way to get to the file listing for an unmodified file.
fields.summary: Provide a way to browse the file tree and view/log/blame files without editing them

fields.description: Please make interface with tabs. It much easier to work :)
fields.summary: Please make interface with tabs

fields.description:
When working on a branch and merging from master, one often doesn't care about the details of the commits that were made to master.
When working on master and a branch has been merged in, even if it was not a squash merge so as to preserve the branch's history, most developers often don't care about the individual commits that went to the branch.
All the extra commit lines are making it more difficult to follow the history of the branch and are taking up screen real estate.

Support for log's --first-parent option in the GUI would provide a cleaner view of log history. Maybe as a third option next to "All Branches" and "Current Branch"
fields.summary: Support for first-parent option in log view

fields.description:
How to reproduce (with Hg repo on BitBucket, auto refresh rate is set to every minute.):

Machine A) Work on some code > Commit via sourcetree, push via sourcetree.

Machine B) Open sourcetree, Bookmarks window never shows the pull requests until i explicitly open the bookmarked project in question.

Also if source-tree added a warning that you were about to commit or push to a repository that has pending pull requests that would save a lot of annoyances also.
fields.summary: Bookmarks window doesn't automatically show pending pull requests

fields.description:
After completing a hg-flow feature or release/hotfix, the Push toolbar buttons don't show there's something to push until the next remote refresh. We should try to escalate this as we do for commit/merge etc.

One caveat is that the number of commits that will be ready to push could be > 1, since finishing a hotfix merges twice for example.
fields.summary: Update the push markers when finishing a hg-flow feature/release/hotfix

fields.description:
When performing a Push or Pull (I'm using Git), and the operation completes while Mission Control is active, the progress and sheet window will detach from the rep window without any way to close them.

Steps to reproduce:
1. Do a push or pull.
2. After the sheet drops down, press OK.
3. While the progress sheet drops, go into Mission Control.
4. Wait for the operation to finish and the dialog to go away.
5. Leave mission control.
6. Move the main repo window, or enter Mission Control again and notice the progress and push/pull sheet dialog are still open, but detached from the parent window.
fields.summary: Push/Pull sheet gets orphaned when in mission control

fields.description: It would be nice of I could change the size of the commit message text area. If I write a long commit message I would like to see the hole content.
fields.summary: Change the commit message text area size

fields.description: When reviewing commits for a specific repository, the "Commit" column displays the 7 characters particular commit hash. It would be very practical, for developers like me who like also to use the command line, and also link to tickets in JIRA on code completion to be able to quickly copy that hash. I don't see an easy way of doing that. It would be nice to add it as an option to the right click context menu for that particular commit line just like the Merge, Rebase etc options.
fields.summary: Ability to easily copy commit hash

fields.description:
The problem:
Often we need to put in debugging code that we do not want to commit. Often these files get accidentally committed.

The solution:
Ability to flag these files as "Do not commit" (or something similar).
Display a small icon next to these files.
Perhaps even go down to the level of a hunk and allow users to flag an individual hunk.
fields.summary: Ability to flag tracked files as "Do not commit"

fields.description:
In log view one can search for user, file changes or commit message.

It would be helpful to be able to search for file names. Then all commits should be shown which changed this file.

This is more than "Log selected". With that only the changes in the selected files are shown but not the changes in other files in the same commit.
fields.summary: Extend log view to search all commits containing changes in a file

fields.description:
I often jump between a few Repos in the course of work.  When using OS X Lion Full Screen mode, I can't immediately tell which window is for which project.

I've begun just having all the windows not in FS mode, but in their own numbered desktop.  
This is perfectly adequate for now, but I thought I would raise the issue.

Thank you for the awesome product!
fields.summary: When using multiple windows using Lion Full Screen Mode, there's no immediate indicator as to which repo any particular window is for.

fields.description:
In ST, define 2 different hosted accounts for BitBucket (BB). Then you get something similar to "Screen Shot 2012-09-14 at 7.11.00 PM.png"

Then if login to BB with safari with one of the account and refresh the list of hosted accounts in SourceTree, the list i smessed up...Project Name seems to appear twice for the user account that is logged in to BB under Safari. And not all the Project names appear anymore for the second account (see attachment Screen Shot 2012-09-14 at 7.12.06 PM.png). 

This is not happening if you try to reproduce with Chrome web browser.
fields.summary: The hosted repositories list appears incorrect

fields.description: "Current Branch" mode is great for focusing on the history of the branch you've got checked out, but sometimes you need to focus on a different branch.  There's currently no way to do that except to check out the other branch, which may be impractical.  It would be nice if the "Current" in "Current Branch" referred to the currently *selected* branch instead of the currently checked-out branch.
fields.summary: Allow log to be filtered by branches other than the current branch

fields.description:
1. Create and commit two files, foo.h and foo.c
2. Make changes to both files.
3. In SourceTree, multi-select foo.h and foo.c in the "Files in the working tree pane".
4. Stage some changes from the diff view by clicking "Stage". Make sure to leave some unstaged changes in both files and to leave both files multi-selected in the "Files in the working tree" pane. This is the crucial step.
5. Click commit.
6. Change "Selected Files" to "Staged changes" in the commit mode chooser. Note that there is a disabled checked checkbox next to each staged file and a disabled unchecked checkbox next to each unstaged file.
7. While the commit dialog is open, edit and save one of the files.
8. Switch back to SourceTree.

Expected:
I can now commit.

Actual:
The disabled checkboxes next to the staged files change to unchecked, the disabled checkboxes next to the unstaged files change to checked. When clicking on commit, the error dialog "No staged changes!" pops up.

Workaround: Select "Selected Files" as a "Commit mode" and select back "Staged changes" after step 8
fields.summary: unexpected "No staged changes!"

fields.description: I work in a large team using Source Tree for git versioning. It would be great, if Sourcetree could check periodically for new commits to pull and place a dock icon if something is new similar to the badge on the "Pull" button
fields.summary: Dock icon Badge

fields.description:
When I have a changeset highlighted in the search or log view, it would be nice to be able to type cmd-c to get a copy of the changeset information to paste into an email or testing note.  I picture that this would default to a concise 1-line view and be customizable with a preference.

Perhaps something like this as a default, or maybe a date in there, too:
'{rev}\t{desc|firstline}\n'
fields.summary: Cmd-C to copy changeset information

fields.description:
I often move a file on filesystem-basis and get a "missing" and a "untracked" file in SourceTree. To commit this moved file correctly, I'll have to undo the move-operation in Finder and use the "Move..."-feature in SourceTree.

It would be great to have a feature "Moved file..." in the context-menu of a untracked file, that will show up a dialog to choose the previous location of the file, so that Hg will then correctly show my move-operation even if I didn't move it in SourceTree, but with Finder.
(Vice versa: Select new location of a missing file would be great, too.)

(see attached screenshot)
fields.summary: Improvement of "Move...": "This is a moved file"

fields.description: I tried to use a tilde in the path in the git Create Patch dialog. The error result is also obtuse.
fields.summary: Support Tildes in paths

fields.description:
Currently commit graph seems to randomly choose the colours for branches. To make the graph easier to read, I would like to be able to configure the colours for given branches. For example, always use cyan for "master" and yellow for "develop", and never use those colours for other branches, even if "master" and "develop" are not visible.

In addition a configuration which would use a bolder line for the current branch might make the graph easier to read.
fields.summary: Fixed colour for given branch name in graph view

fields.description:
When directly rightclicking a Bookmark and using Menu Item 'Show in Finder' a wrong location (other Repo) is opened in Finder. By directly rightclicking I mean not previously leftclicking a Bookmark, so it's selected (background color different).

Expected behavior:
Open the folder of the repository represented by the Bookmark that got rightclicked.

Conclusion:
Wrong Bookmark is used for the location to be opened.

Assumption:
I guess you determine the clickedRow as cells don't get selected, when they are rightclicked. The bug may be there.
fields.summary: 'Show in Finder' doesn't work correctly when directly rightclicking Bookmark

fields.description:
I opened up the File Menu command "install command line tools" by mistake.  I cancelled out of it, and got two error messages.  

Cancelling should be painless.
fields.summary: Cancelling out of Install Command Line Tools results in an error (actually two of them)

fields.description:
Using Menu > Actions > Show In Finder, SourceTree *** does *** open the folder window and locates the selected file in the folder structure. *** But ***, there is no keyboard shortcut associated with the action. Command-click is Apple's default shortcut for the action.

Implement shortcut command-click to Show In Finder the current selected file
fields.summary: Implement shortcut command-click to Show selected file in finder (similar to Apple)

fields.description:
I used Blame and found some lines from a really old commit (2 years and many revisions ago).  When trying to "View in File Log" the commit never loaded. The file had moved so the Follow Rename option has to be enabled for the changeset to appear in the list.  It might be nice to have this option on by default when performing a reveal from Blame. 

Also when trying "View in Repository History", the revision was never selected either.  However, if I copy the sha1 I can locate it using "Jump To" Commit in the repo history.

On this note, there isn't an option to copy the SHA1 hash from the blame window.
fields.summary: View commit from Blame window doesn't always work with old commits

fields.description:
"push" to svn is not the same as like "svn dcommit", isn't it?!

When a git-flow release is finished, and I hit
{{$ git co svntrunk && svn dcommit}}
just the merge from {{release}} will be "pushed".

before: r2
after:  r3

nevertheless there are 10 patches in git release

Doing a "push" after  {{git flow release finish}} in SourceTree, will svn rebase first and you can't deny this. This will cause each patch will be applied on top and committed each:

before: r2
after:  r12

It would be nice to get something like: "rebase svn before merging release branch" to 
a) get the newest changes from SVN
b) "squash" the release as a single commit as like it happens on console

to complete the environment:

{noformat}[core]
    repositoryformatversion = 0
    filemode = true
    bare = false
    logallrefupdates = true
    ignorecase = true
[svn-remote "svn"]
    url = https://svn.example.com/svn/repo
    fetch = trunk:refs/remotes/trunk
    branches = branches/*:refs/remotes/*
    tags = tags/*:refs/remotes/tags/*
[remote "origin"]
    url = gitosis@git.example.com:repo.git
    fetch = +refs/heads/*:refs/remotes/origin/*
    tags = tags/*:refs/heads/tags/*
[branch "master"]
    remote = origin
    merge = refs/heads/master
[branch "svntrunk"]
    remote = .
    merge = refs/remotes/trunk
[gitflow "branch"]
    master = svntrunk
    develop = master
[gitflow "prefix"]
    feature = feature/
    release = release/
    hotfix = hotfix/
    support = support/
    versiontag =
[receive]
    denyCurrentBranch = refuse
{noformat}

{noformat}[color]
    diff = auto
    status = auto
    branch = auto
[alias]
    st = status
    ci = commit
    co = checkout
    nffmerge = merge --no-ff --no-commit
    ffmerge = merge --ff-only
    llog = log --branches --graph --decorate=full
    llogr = log --branches --graph --decorate=full --remotes
    tags = tag -ln
    br = branch -vv
    brr = branch -avv
    unstage = reset HEAD --
    untrack = rm --cached
    ignore = update-index --assume-unchanged
    unignore = update-index --no-assume-unchanged
    wtm = show-merges
    wtmr = show-remote-merges
    gcp = gc --aggressive --prune=0
    track = branch --set-upstream
    poh = push -u origin HEAD
    pohf = push --force -u origin HEAD
    nm = branch --no-merge
    pulls = pull --recurse-submodules
    p = puffpu origin HEAD
    cpu = puffpu --commit origin HEAD
[user]
    name = Marcel Silberhorn
    email = coder@childno.de
[difftool "sourcetree"]
    cmd = opendiff \"$LOCAL\" \"$REMOTE\"
    path =
[mergetool "sourcetree"]
    cmd = /Applications/SourceTree.app/Contents/Resources/opendiff-w.sh \"$LOCAL\" \"$REMOTE\" -ancestor \"$BASE\" -merge \"$MERGED\"
    trustExitCode = true
[core]
    excludesfile = ~/.gitignore_global
[branch]
    autosetupmerge = true
[fetch]
    recurseSubmodules = true
{noformat}
fields.summary: Git Flow release not working the same as on console with git-svn

fields.description:
Clean up Road Map - correct Version order and close old, released Versions
https://jira.atlassian.com/browse/SRCTREE#selectedTab=com.atlassian.jira.plugin.system.project%3Aroadmap-panel

^^ still shows 1.3.4 etc. ahead 1.6 not finished!?
fields.summary: Clean up Road Map - correct Version order and close old, released Versions

fields.description: It would be very nice to be able to enter a revsets expression somewhere and see the matching revisions. This could be implemented for example by allowing to enter a revsets expression in the "Search" view's "Enter a string to search for" field (and probably choosing a new "Revsets" entry from the "Search" combobox).
fields.summary: Display result of revsets expression
Git flow finish feature with rebase option errors with 'flow is not a git command'

fields.description:
I love source tree.  One thing that would make my life even better is if you could add support for enterprise github.  My company licenses github and runs our own instance.  However when I try to add an account I can't edit the URL field.  Could you please allow this field to be editable?  The protocols should be the same as the public github, just at a different URL.

Thanks!
fields.summary: Support Enterprise Github

fields.description:
If a file name changes from abc.json to ABC.json; SourceTree doesn't differentiate between the file name change.
However, I can commit the file and do diffs, but the filename always shows up in lowercase in SourceTree.
fields.summary: SourceTree doesn't pickup changes in file case names

fields.description:
It would be great to expose the line numbers for the current diff pane selection in the Custom Action parameters.

Requested [here|http://redirect.disqus.com/url?url=http%3A%2F%2Fblog.sourcetreeapp.com%2F2012%2F02%2F08%2Fcustom-actions-more-power-to-you%2F%23comment-632135435%3AJjHDk54UDJVWrqPZ0xewRMHvpRY&imp=e053b90e-583e-404a-8e43-d04f564f04f6&zone=notifications.clicks&forum=sourcetreeblog&thread=568823632].
fields.summary: Support LINENO variable(s) in custom actions

fields.description:
At the command line, using "hg cat" (not sure about git, maybe "git show"), I can extract a given revision of a file from my repository.  A common use is to save a copy of the particular file revision outside of the working directory or to a different name within the working directory.

e.g.  hg cat -o outputfile.c -r revision somefile.c

Though this could probably be scripted to a "Custom Action", I think it may be useful enough to see as an option in the Log and Branch views.  When one right-clicks on a file (branch view) or log entry (log view) the pop-up menu contains an option to Save that revision of the file somewhere via a standard file Save dialogue.
fields.summary: Extract and Save any revision of  file from a repository

fields.description:
When I try to install the command line helper from sourcetree I get an error message telling me to look in the logs. Here's what I found:
8/24/12 10:54:03.538 AM launchdadd: FAILURE: Code <SecCode 0x7fc932101870 [0x7fff751cdfa0]> failed requirement (identifier "com.torusknot.SourceTreeNotMAS" and certificate leaf[subject.CN] = "3rd Party Mac Developer Application: Torus Knot Software Ltd") with error "The operation couldn't be completed. (OSStatus error -67050.)"
8/24/12 10:54:03.538 AM launchdadd: FAILURE: Code <SecStaticCode 0x7fc9321ac470 [0x7fff751cdfa0]> failed requirement (identifier "com.atlassian.SourceTreePrivilegedHelper" and certificate leaf[subject.CN] = "Developer ID Application: Atlassian Pty Ltd") with error "The operation couldn't be completed. (OSStatus error -67050.)"
8/24/12 10:54:03.538 AM launchdadd: FAILURE: Job com.atlassian.SourceTreePrivilegedHelper could not be installed from /Apps/Developer/SourceTree.app/Contents/Library/LaunchServices/com.atlassian.SourceTreePrivilegedHelper, reason 3.
8/24/12 10:54:03.539 AM SourceTree: Failed to install privileged helper: Error Domain=kSMErrorDomainFramework Code=3 "The operation couldn't be completed. (kSMErrorDomainFramework error 3 - The client and tool did not match requirements.)" UserInfo=0x4001e8560 {NSDescription=The client and tool did not match requirements.}
I'm running OS X Lion 10.7.4
fields.summary: Cannot install sourcetree command line tools

fields.description:
When the OS is restarted/shut down and booted up again, and instructed to re-open the current windows on startup, SourceTree correctly remembers most settings and will open up a window to where it left off. However, it does not remember which desktop/space it was one. For example, if I have SourceTree on Desktop 2 (as soon in the Mission Control display of the OS), and I restart, SourceTree will always place its window on Desktop 1.

The proper behavior would have SourceTree reopen its window on Desktop 2, as it was left. This minimizes discontinuity between restarts and allows the user to continue working exactly where they left off, as if the restart never happened.
fields.summary: Window should remember which desktop its on between restarts

fields.description:
I'm attaching a .zip file with five git repositories containing a simple text file.

"initial" contains the start repository - two unmerged branches.

"after_merge_with_git", "after_merge_with_sourcetree", 

"after_rebase_with_git", and "after_rebase_with_sourcetree" are the same repository after the corresponding git/sourcetree command.

"after_rebase_with_sourcetree" in particular was obtained by merging the two branches ("master" and "fork") using the "Rebase instead of merge" option. It seems that the normal, non-fast-forward merge is obtained there, which is unexppected if compared to after_rebase_with_git.
fields.summary: [GIT] "Rebase instead of merge" option in the merge dialog does not seem to work correctly

fields.description: The context menu for the current local branch has a Pull item on it usually. However, when the branch is a 'nested' name the item doesn't appear.
fields.summary: Sidebar context menu doesn't show pull on current branch if nested

fields.description: We sign commits for accountability purposes (git commit -S). It would be great if there were an easy way to do that via the SourceTree commit button.
fields.summary: Sign Git Commits

fields.description:
My password expired on our git and svn servers. The git password change was properly handled with a dialog prompting for the new password.

The svn password is apparently used under the hood by git-svn. It didn't fare so well:

git -c diff.mnemonicprefix=false -c core.quotepath=false fetch ironside 


git -c diff.mnemonicprefix=false -c core.quotepath=false svn fetch 
Authentication realm: <http://svn2.ship.scea.com:80> Subversion Repository
Password for 'arosenberg': 
Authentication realm: <http://svn2.ship.scea.com:80> Subversion Repository
Username: Use of uninitialized value $username in chomp at /Volumes/Data/Applications/SourceTree.app/Contents/Resources/git_local/lib/perl5/site_perl/Git/SVN/Prompt.pm line 114.
error: git-svn died of signal 11
Completed with errors, see above

Going to the command line and doing a git svn fetch and then typing in the proper credentials appears to resolve this. All of the passwords in Keychain Access that are for these servers were already updated with the new password but this error still persisted.
fields.summary: Mishandling of password change

fields.description:
Git supports the use of hooks in order to involve custom scripts when e.g. doing a commit. In our specific case, we use Ruby scripts and rely on a custom ruby build installed via rvm.
Unfortunately when using SourceTree, the wrong ruby version is always being picked as well as the wrong gem path.

Currently the app does not apply any settings defined in the .profile or other configuration files.
Since OS X 10.8 no longer supports the environment.plist file, applications themselves seem to be responsible to read custom variables.

It would be nice to be able to define custom environmental variables within the app, or be able to read in configuration files like .profile
fields.summary: Support for environmental variables

fields.description: We should treat this as a one-off selection and not set the global preference. This means we should only read the global preference when opening the dialog, and then detach and changes to it from the global preference.
fields.summary: Checking the 'no fast forward' option in the merge/gitflow dialogs shouldn't set global default

fields.description: The dialogue that's bugging me currently is "Confirm discard changes?". It often happens that I have to walk through the changes in the working directory and discard some and having to answer the same question on every step is extremely annoying. It would be nice to be able to turn it off
fields.summary: Power-user mode with the annoying confirmation dialogues turned-off

fields.description: Support for the basic suit of AppleScript functions would be amazing so the application can be launched and the windows polled and controlled from AppleScript.
fields.summary: Adding minimal AppleScript Support

fields.description:
Several users have requested the ability to open files with a non-default editor (i.e. not the one picked by NSWorkspace, which is derived from Finder associations).

So far we've resisted this because Apple say you're not supposed to do it, and indeed the Sandbox expressly prevents it. However, since we're now no longer going to try to satisfy the Sandbox requirements and are not committing to continuing App Store support, we could potentially implement this.

Of course if we reviewed our App Store / Sandboxing position later, this would be one more thing we'd have to turn off.
fields.summary: "Open With" support

fields.description: When sourcetree is started the browser scrollbar is fine. Only when I manually resize the window the issue appears. When I slowly shrink the window I can see the scrollbar jumping between two sizes: "Ok" and "too short". So when I stop resizing at the wrong moment the scrollbar is too short. This aint a big problem as I can simply resize it again until the scrollbar is fine.
fields.summary: Bookmarks view scrollbar is too short after manual resizing

fields.description:
Would like a way to see the actual commands that source tree runs, and easily run my own commands.

My idea would be to have a hide-able view that shows all of the commands and results that source tree runs on a repo.  Then, also allow for manual command entry in the window as a short cut to do custom events.

We are just trying to make sure that using source tree doesn't promote ignorance on the actual git commands being run.
fields.summary: Add view to see terminal commands, and allow for manual command entry

fields.description:
This produces a following error message: {code}"error: pathspec '[PATH TO THE NEW FILE]' did not match any file(s) known to git."{code}

I suspect this is closely related to https://jira.atlassian.com/browse/SRCTREE-1163
fields.summary: Clicking "Reset" from a context menu on a file move action in the "Files staged in index" list results in error

fields.description: Note: Git-specific, Mercurial is OK here.
fields.summary: "Reset" and "Stash" buttons are disabled when there's only a move action in the "Files staged in index"

fields.description: To me it seems fine that this action breaks up into deleted file and unstaged file in "Files in the working tree", what's not fine is that it requires 2 drags for it to be actually moved from "Files staged in the index" to "Files in the working tree". A fine solution IMO would be to simply make it work in a single drag-and-drop operation.
fields.summary: Dragging a file move action from "Files staged in the index" to "Files in the working tree" leaves a delete action in the first list

fields.description: Contrary to that this dialogue doesn't get opened when multiple files are selected
fields.summary: Clicking "Reset" button in "File Status" view with a single file selected opens a redundant "Discard File Changes" dialogue

fields.description:
The current repository has both staged and unstaged modifications.
When I now select the stash action and select the above option, SourceTree does stash all modifications, just as it would without the option.
The difference is that it afterwards still has the modifications in the index.
From the description of the option, I would've expected the stash to only contain untagged modifications but not any indexed.
fields.summary: Stash option "keep index (only stash unstaged changes)" is broken

fields.description:
When installing the tools from the menu item ("Install Command Line Tools"), an error is shown (see attachment). The system log dumps the following error:

Aug  9 09:29:39 Maclet.local WindowServer[207]: [cps/setfront] Failed setting the front application to SourceTree, psn 0x0-0x86e86e, securitySessionID=0x186a7, err=-13066
Aug  9 09:29:39 Maclet.local com.apple.SecurityServer[18]: Succeeded authorizing right 'com.apple.ServiceManagement.blesshelper' by client '/usr/libexec/launchdadd' [78112] for authorization created by '/Applications/SourceTree.app' [78056] (100003,0)
Aug  9 09:29:39 Maclet.local launchdadd[78112]: FAILURE: Code <SecCode 0x7fd3529018e0 [0x7fff7682b190]> failed requirement (identifier "com.torusknot.SourceTreeNotMAS" and certificate leaf[subject.CN] = "3rd Party Mac Developer Application: Torus Knot Software Ltd") with error "The operation couldn’t be completed. (OSStatus error -67050.)"
Aug  9 09:29:39 Maclet.local launchdadd[78112]: FAILURE: Code <SecStaticCode 0x7fd352b007a0 [0x7fff7682b190]> failed requirement (identifier "com.atlassian.SourceTreePrivilegedHelper" and certificate leaf[subject.CN] = "Developer ID Application: Atlassian Pty Ltd") with error "The operation couldn’t be completed. (OSStatus error -67050.)"
Aug  9 09:29:39 Maclet.local launchdadd[78112]: FAILURE: Job com.atlassian.SourceTreePrivilegedHelper could not be installed from /Applications/SourceTree.
fields.summary: Sourcetree fails to install command line tools
Custom Action: Multiple parameters get quoted together incorrectly

fields.description:
Sometimes I do the diff between commits with a lot of files and other times I looking inside the diff file for a specific change.
It would be great to have a search box on the bottom that look into the current diff (both in file name and diff in the files). It can have a next/previous buttons that navigate between the occurrences.
fields.summary: Search on file panel and diff panel

fields.description:
See comments by Timothy Robb here: 
https://answers.atlassian.com/questions/54469/how-do-i-perform-a-forced-push-push-f-from-sourcetree?page=1#comment-75151

Upshot is that for the minority of people that do use a workflow which requires force pushing, not supporting it is an issue. However, we don't want to offer it lightly, because it could be abused by people who don't understand the impact fully.

Proposed approach:
# Option in Preferences to 'Allow force push'. Only when this option is enabled should the force push checkbox appear on the Push dialog
# Using the force push option on the push dialog should still show a warning (with a 'Don't tell me again' checkbox)
# The 'force' option should never be remembered in the push dialog
fields.summary: Force push option, only displayed via opt-in in Preferences

fields.description: I'm using SourceTree 1.5.2 with Git flow support. I noticed that if you set up Git flow and use a "feature branch prefix" of "" (don't enter anything in the text field), then SourceTree mistakenly thinks that "develop" is a feature branch, even if it has explicitly been specified as being the name of the development branch. This problem does not occur with the branch "master".
fields.summary: Git flow mishandles branches when the feature branch prefix is empty

fields.description:
When I connect to a bitbucket (private) repository I get the attached error.

This is in fact happening because Mercurial is not installe don the machine.

The error message wasn't in an user readable manner. It was
taking the whole screen. That may need to be handled and fixed.
fields.summary: 'invalid char in json text' while connecting to bitbucket repository

fields.description:
Large projects can have large numbers of tiny branches created by merging when different people are working on different things.

This can make the view very hard to use with the graph drawing lines every which way making it almost impossible to follow the line back.

I suggest adding the option to collapse the right side of all multi-parent commits. And providing buttons to collapse and uncollapse all of them.

I included a screenshot of the history of one large project. And an edited version where all commits not part of the leftmost side of the history are hidden.

The UI would be a little better than my edited image. And would probably have some sort of collapse icon.

The right arrow key should expand a branch while the left arrow key would collapse it.

In projects that use things like pre-commit review with Gerrit or some other system or have maintainers that handle the master tree and answer pull requests with merges this kind of view should make it much easier to read the history.
fields.summary: Allow the right side of a repo's history to be collapsed

fields.description: My project uses git cherry-pick -x <SHA> to preserve history when cherry picking. SourceTree should provide a way to set this. Either as a preference for all git cherry-pick commands or in a dialog box when performing the cherry pick.
fields.summary: Cherry pick does not allow me to add options

fields.description: I would like to see the ability to have all repositories in a given folder show up in my SourceTree list. I like the ability to add groups and individual repositories, but I often have directories with 10+ repositories in them. It would be nice for them to just show up instead of having to add and remove them individually.
fields.summary: View all repositories in a folder instead of adding them individually

fields.description:
We have config repositories with lots of branches. It would be really great if the amount of shown branch labels in the log view could be filtered e.g. 

test002_env_* || standard_env_*

would only display:
standard_env_live
standard_env_prep
test002_env_live
test002_env_prep


for branches:
standard_env_live
standard_env_prep
...
test001_env_live
test001_env_prep
test002_env_live
test002_env_prep
...
...
fields.summary: Show only branches matching an expression in Log View

fields.description:
Has been requested twice now and is quite awkward to do.

The main reason this wasn't exposed is because there are 2 pull requests I created on the standard git-flow which are required to be in place: 
https://github.com/nvie/gitflow/pull/222
https://github.com/nvie/gitflow/pull/223

Both of those have now been accepted into the upstream git-flow, but they're still only on the 'develop' branch and haven't been merged into 'master' so any default checkout of git-flow still wouldn't have them. 

We'd need to perhaps detect whether the patches have been applied, or perhaps more reliably ask the user.
fields.summary: Add ability to use custom git-flow
To show the log history on a subfolder.

fields.description: SourceTree 1.5.1 does not seem to be stable on OS X Lion 10.7.2 (11C74). See attached stack traces
fields.summary: SourceTree 1.5.1 unstable on OS X 10.7.2

fields.description:
Requested by: https://answers.atlassian.com/questions/72804/how-to-disable-bookmarks

Some users would prefer if the Bookmarks window never opened, even if there were no other windows to open. Could be a new Preferences option.
fields.summary: Add Preferences option to never open Bookmarks window at startup

fields.description: Click on the Git flow button, answer next screen, then hit submit. See warning dialog that mentions HG Flow instead of Git Flow.
fields.summary: Bad Warning when Choosing Git Flow button

fields.description:
In OSX applications the default shortcut is cmd-ctrl-f for fullscreen. In SourceTree this shortcut does not work.
There is also not a menu item available for fullscreen making it impossible to add the shortcut manually by the OSX app specific keyboard preferences.
fields.summary: Add default OSX fullscreen shortcut (cmd-ctrl-f)

fields.description:
I have created a Custom Action for removing trailing whitespace from a file (by calling a Bash Script (see attachment)); this uses the $FILE parameter (see screenshot).
From "File Status View", in the "Files staged in the index" and "Files in the working tree", the Custom Action will work as expected.
From "Log View", in the same two lists, the Custom Action is enabled but will not run when clicked. The output from Console.app has been included.
fields.summary: File Custom Actions do not work from Uncommited Changes

fields.description:
When unstaging a staged hunk, or trying to discard a unstaged hunk,
the button resulted no action nothing.
fields.summary: Unstage hunk, and discard hunk are no-ops

fields.description:
When a directory is selected in, for example, 'Files in working tree' view,
the diff view doesn't show anything. It would be useful for showing the full subtree diff, for quickly scanning if any of those changes are relevant for the commit I'm building up, or if I've forgotten some debug code in there.
fields.summary: Show diff of subtree selection

fields.description:
Very minor, but it always catches me off guard...

When doing any checking in, pushing, pulling, etc the log window (when you select 'Show Full Output') shows updates in red. However, this always looks like a bunch of errors due to the colour being used :)

Any chance we can change this to say green or blue, and only bring up errors in red?

Example output attached, although this doesn't show much!
fields.summary: Change colour of text from Red in the log windows

fields.description:
It would be nice to have a context menu for previous commit messages so we can copy them from the UI into other applications / emails / tracking systems easily.

Currently Command-C does work to copy, but you'd expect right-clicking would allow for this too.

Attached is a screenshot with a mock-up of what might be expected.
fields.summary: Right click in previous commit message should show editing context menu

fields.description:
if there are only whitespace changes and "ignore whitespace" is set then the diff pane says "unmodified file".
However, that's not how I interpret the word "unmodified". (I'd use that word to describe a file, not a diff — and I see now the message is even explicit that it's saying the file is unmodified, which isn't true.) At least, I think it's confusing in a way that could be avoided with a more specific message. (perhaps "only whitespace differences"). Again, I may be an outlier, but this did throw me for a loop of confusion over the state of my repository, and I think a more specific message would not throw anybody off.
fields.summary: "Unmodified file" for files differing only in whitespace

fields.description: Add an option to the main Git merge sheet to support the --squash option.
fields.summary: Add --squash option to git merge

fields.description:
Tried to create a custom action to run a command line tool "p4" (perforce).
Execution of the script is never attempted by sourcetree.
However, add a character "p44" and it will at least try.

Unfortunately, even adding the full path "/usr/bin/p4" doesn't work.
fields.summary: Can't run custom actions if "Script to run" is less than 3 characters

fields.description:
How to reproduce:
1. setup a BitBucket account
2. input wrong username/password
3. submit

Look like ST gets the whole HTML page instead simple string/object.

see attached screenshot
fields.summary: When BitBucket account login failed, the warning message doesn't make sense.

fields.description:
It'd be nice to be able to change the order of where custom actions appear in the context menu when right-clicking a file.
Currently it appears that whatever order the custom actions are created in are the final order it appears in.
Possibly adding a couple of move selection up / down buttons would be sufficient.
fields.summary: Change order of custom actions menu
